Facts.Fact: Son of King Archidamos II and Eupolia
Half-brother of King Agis II and Teleutias

Agesilaos was born in 444/3 and about 402 married Kleora (cf.
Aristomenidas) who bore him three children
after the death of Agis II in the summer of 399

Agesilaos—particularly through the
influence of his boyhood friend Lysander—received the
throne.<sup>Cujg</sup>

through the efforts of Lysander was Agesilaos appointed the
commander in the war against Persia. He sailed in the spring of 396 from
Aulis to Ephesus.<sup>kCh</sup>
He conducted the war in Asia Minor until the summer of 394

when he
was recalled because of political developments in
Greece.<sup>Cxwlva</sup>
In thirty days he marched to Boeotia

where he established a camp at
Chaeroneia on the 25th or 26th of August 394 and soon thereafter
defeated the enemies of Sparta in the battle of
Coronea.<sup>Cm</sup>

To heal the wound that he had received in the battle he took himself
to Delphi and from there travelled home on a ship.<sup>Cx</sup>

In 391 he laid waste to Argos and continued on to Corinth where he
had the long walls of Lechaeum torn down.<sup>Cy</sup>

In the summer of the next year <390> he was active at the
Isthmus<sup>Cop</sup>. There he fought on behalf of the Achaeans against
the Acarnanians.<sup>Cp</sup>

At the peace conference in Sparta in 387/6 he forced through the
recognition of the King’s Peace on the part of the Thebans and the
dissolution of the just founded city Corinth-Argos.<sup>Cz</sup>
In the fall of 381 he struck against Phlius

which he took after a
siege of twenty months.<sup>C</sup>

In similar fashion he participated in the great struggle between
Thebes and Sparta. He undertook two operations to Boeotia in 378/7. A
wound
which he received on the march back

kept him from the theater of
war for a long time

<sup>Cb</sup> so he acted all the more energetically
against Thebes in 371 at the congress at Sparta

when he excluded the
Thebans from the common peace.<sup>Cq</sup>

After the catastrophe at Leuctra he campaigned with the full army
against Mantinea

but had to withdraw to Sparta at the approach of the
Thebans.<sup>C</sup> By his careful handling he saved the country from
the invasion of Epaminondas in the winter of 370/69.<sup>r</sup>

Around 364 he travelled to Asia to earn money for Sparta and fought
there together with the Athenian Timotheos for the interests of
Ariobarzanes.<sup>Af</sup>
In 362 we find the king back in Greece

where shortly before the
battle of Mantinea he saved Sparta a second time from a Theban
invasion.<sup>Csc</sup>
In 361 he went to Egypt to enter the service of Tachos

to earn money
for Sparta as the leader of a mercenary band. When he was demoted by
Tachos he went over to Nectanebo and did important service for him.
Therefore
when he prepared his return home

he was loaded with rich
gifts. He never reached his homeland

but died in the winter of 360/59
between Egypt and Cyrene in the “harbor of Menelaos.” His body was
brought back to Sparta.<sup>tde</sup>

A Spartiate who was sent by Agesilaos II to Memphis during the time
when Plato was travelling in Egypt. We do not have an exact date for
Plato’s Egyptian stay. Plato left Athens after the death of Socrates and
travelled through the Peloponnesus, to Egypt and Cyrene. In 388 he had
already visited Syracuse again. The trip of Agetoridas then, if it is at
all historical, must fall in the period 399-388.

He was the eponymous king of the house of the Agids—obviously a
mythical person<sup>ab</sup>.

During his reign (1061-1030/29) the helots were
subjugated<sup>c</sup>. He is also made the ultimate ancestor of the
mythical Amphikles<sup>d</sup>.
King from the house of the Eurypontids

After the death of Archidamos Agis assumed the throne in
427/6<sup>k</sup>. In the years 426 and 425 he twice led the army into
Attica.<sup>ab</sup> With his fellow king Pleistoanax in 421 he
underwrote the peace of Nicias and the alliance with
Athens.<sup>c</sup>
In 419 he marched with the assembled army to Leuctra

but turned back
to Sparta without accomplishing anything.<sup>d</sup> In the next summer
he campaigned twice against the Argives and besieged them because of
their alliance with Mantinea<sup>em</sup>. In a third campaign at the
beginning of the winter of 417 he caused the newly built walls of Argos
to be torn down<sup>f</sup>.
In spring 413 Agis invaded Attica and seized Decelea

where he
remained as commander<sup>g</sup>. From here he undertook in the
following winter a campaign against the Oitaians and the Achaeans living
in Phthiotis

to reestablish the influence of the Spartans on the Malean
Gulf<sup>h</sup>. From Decelea Agis supported all rebellions against
Athens in Asia Minor and along the Hellespont and tried several times to
take the city<sup>io</sup>. He did not take part in the siege of Athens
in 405/4<sup>nq</sup>

although he did offer his good ofices to the
Athenians<sup>p</sup>.

After the fall of Athens he led a long campaign against
Elis<sup>t</sup> and visited Delphi. On his return trip he fell sick and
died soon after his arrival in Sparta

He succeeded his father in 338 and ruled for nine years<sup>d</sup>.
In 333
as leader of the opposition to Alexander the Great

Agis
travelled to Siphnos to meet Pharnabazos and Autophradates

the
commanders of the Persian fleet; he obtained money and troops from them.
Then he travelled to Halicarnassos where he led some of the survivors of
the Greek mer­cenaries from the battle of Issos to Crete<sup>ce</sup>.
After he returned to Sparta he besieged Megalopolis

but in a battle
fought there against Antipater

and
Gylippos) fell at Messene sometime after 369.

Facts.Fact:
The poet of Laconian choral lyric from the second half of the seventh
century. Over his antecedents there is no agreement. (1) Alcman came
from Sardis<sup>a</sup>. Added to that is the reference that Alcman was
the slave of the Lacedaemonian Agesidas<sup>b</sup>. (2)
Elsewhere<sup>c</sup> the poet is described as Λάκων ἀπὸ Μεσσόας and is
given Damas or Titaros as his father. (3) Ale­xan­der the
Aetolian<sup>d</sup> takes a middle position in an epigram; he holds
Alcman for a Laconian

but says that his ancestors came from Sardis. In
a mosaic portrait bust Alcman was associated with Sappho and
Anacreon<sup>e</sup>.

refers to Areus I

since it seemed unlikely to him that the Delphians
would grant proxenia to a child

was not a king. There is but one king Akrotatos and
he is the father of Areus II. Moreover

the Chilonis of the inscription
might well be the widow of Kleonymus and lover of Akrotatos the king
[26.17-18].)

Father of Agis II (from his first marriage with his step-aunt
Lampido)<sup>ab</sup> and Agesilaos II and Kyniska (by his second wife
Eupolia)<sup>acfg</sup>
When shortly before 476 Leotychidas had to go into exile at Tegea

his grandson Archidamos assumed the rule<sup>e</sup>. Whether he had
already taken part in the battles of Tegea in 473 and Dipaia can not be
known. He was first mentioned in the great earthquake in Sparta in 464

where he saved the state through his presence of mind<sup>h</sup>. He
distinguished himself in the ensuing battles against the
Messenians<sup>d</sup>.

Archidamos commanded the first invasion of Attica in the year 431 and
430<sup>klm</sup>. In 429 he took Plataea and in the next year led an
army into Attica for the third time.<sup>no</sup>
He became sick and died at the latest in the Winter 427/6.

Sources.Resource: Athenaeus VII 289e, XII 536cd, XIII 591bw

Facts.Fact: King from the house of the Eurypontids (born about 400)
Son of Agesilaos II and Kleora.

In 371 he led the defeated army of Kleombrotos back from Megara to
Sparta. (Diodorus XV 54-55 in error puts Archidamos also at the battle
of Leuctra.)<sup>bc</sup>

In the years 367 and 364 Archidamos campaigned against the Arcadians
in the field<sup>dei</sup>.

Isokrates put a speech in his mouth that he was supposed to have
delivered at the Peace Congress in Sparta in 366/5<sup>p</sup>.

In 362 he was occupied in the defense of Sparta against the
Thebans<sup>fj</sup>.

After the death of Agesilaos II in the winter of 360/59 he ascended
the throne<sup>k</sup>.

At the outbreak of the Sacred War Archidamos in secret helped the
Phocians<sup>mq</sup>. Around 352 he fought against
Megalopolis<sup>r</sup>
and in 346 led an army to help Phocis

but
because of the ambiguities of the situation among the Phocian leaders
returned to Sparta with nothing accomplished<sup>sv</sup>.

After that he was sent to Italy to help Tarentum in a war against the
Lucanians. He sailed first to Crete where he refounded Lyttos. In Italy
he fought a battle at Mandonion 338—on the seventh of the month
Metageitnion<sup>l</sup>—lost the battle and his
life<sup>gmtuv</sup>.

He had a portrait bust in Olympia<sup>n</sup> and a statue in
Delphi<sup>w</sup>.

Facts.Fact:
In 431 he saved Methone from an Athenian attack<sup>a</sup>. He was
the eponymous ephor of the year 431/30

though he was quite young (but
still met the age qualification)<sup>tv</sup>.

In the next year under the command of Knemos he took part in the sea
battle at Rhion and Naupaktos and in the attack on Salamis<sup>b</sup>.
In the same duty he took part in 427 in the expedition against Corcyra
of Alkidas<sup>cd</sup>. In the battle at Pylos he distinguished himself
and was badly wounded<sup>eu</sup>.

In the next year he gathered his forces in Corinth and Sicyon for the
Thracian expedition and in Autumn 424 reached Thessaly. After a short
march against the Lyncestan king Arrhabaios he turned himself to
Chalcidice and brought over the wavering cities to his side. He fought
from time to time with various fortune against Arrhadaios and the cities
Potidaea and Torone

and in the second half of October 422 triumphed
finally over Kleon in the decisive batttle at Amphipolis

was fatally wounded<sup>fghijkln</sup>. The citizens of
Amphipolis buried him in the city and honored him as hero and
founder<sup>lm</sup>.

In Sparta a cenotaph was erected for him<sup>r</sup>. Brasidas and
the Acanthians had a common treasury in Delphi<sup>p</sup>. Direct
descendants of his are known from Augustan times<sup>q</sup>. The
heroism of Brasidas remained proverbial for a long time<sup>s</sup>.

In 389/8 he was epistoleus of the nauarch Hierax

as such he was
occupied in Aegina. From there he went with Antalkidas, the nauarch of
the next year, to Ephesus and then travelled back to Aegina, where he
defeated the Athenians at sea in a moonlit battle. Soon thereafter he
fell into an ambush in Aegina (set by Chabrias) and was killed along
with eight other Spartiates.

After the death of his father Damaratos began his reign

at the
latest in 510.<sup>c</sup> He was the only one of the Spartan kings to
win the chariot race at Olympia

In spring of 506 he and Cleomenes I led an army against
Athens<sup>f</sup>

Despite the sources he could hardly have taken part in the operation
against Argos in 494.<sup>mp</sup>
As Kleomenes in 491 moved against Aegina

to seize the leaders of the
party friendly to Persia

to
bring this maneuver to nothing.<sup>a</sup>

As revenge for that he was now driven from the throne by Kleomenes
and Leotychidas

Damaratos escaped from Sparta under the pretext of a trip to Delphi
and fled through Elis and Zacynthos to the Persian king
Darius.<sup>eg</sup>

In 480 he accompanied Xerxes on the expedition against
Greece.<sup>hijklnr</sup>

As a reward for his valuable service he received the cities
Teuthrania

and Gambreion after the invasion as his
family possession.<sup>st</sup>

whom he had taken

at the

to

Damaratos escaped from Sparta under the pretext of a trip to Delphi
and fled through Elis and Zacynthos to the Persian king
Darius.<sup>eg</sup>

In 480 he accompanied Xerxes on the expedition against
Greece.<sup>hijklnr</sup>

As a reward for his valuable service he received the cities
Teuthrania

and Gambreion after the invasion as his
family possession.<sup>st</sup>

King at Susa.<sup>o</sup>

Agis after a bath, overpower him, drag him to prison, and execute
him.

Sources.Resource: According to an inscription found in Sparta he and his horses had won victories at different contests. The letter forms seem to indicate the second half of the fifth century. The three ephors named in the inscription do not appear in the list of Xenophon (Hellenica II 3.10), so the inscription must be dated either before 433/2 or after 404/3. That they won over fifty victories, but none in Olympia (Pausanias VI 2.1-2: list of Lacedaemonian victors) suggests that their victories fell in the period when the Spartans were excluded from the Olympic games, 420 to 400 or 396 (Thucydides V 50
Pausanias VI 2.1-3) and that the named ephors held that office after 404/3. The letter forms are not decisive. (contra Moretti!)

A Spartiate whose cleverness earned him the nickname Sisyphos

In 411 he betook himself to the Hellespont and we meet him there as
harmost of Abydos in 407/6.

In 399 in Ephesos he took over the command of the war against Persia
from Thibron and he held it three years. When Agesilaos took over his
command he returned to Sparta in Spring 396. In late summer 394 he
brought the news of the battle of Nemea to Agesilaos in Amphipolis and
continued on to the Hellespont again where he saved Abydos and Sestos
from the allied Athenians and Persians.

Facts.Fact: He was the victor in over one hundred contests

including victories
in the Olympic games at Pisa
and at Sparta the Eurycleian twice

and the Leonidean once. He won the victory games of
M. Aurelius and Commodus and received a gold crown and a
prize.<sup>de</sup>

the Eurycleian games (and others) by M. Aurelius and

He was sent to the Hellespont as the successor of Pausanias, but was
not recognized by the alliance. Since Pausanias, as Leotychidas and
Eurybiades before him, in their position as Spartan nauarch exercised
the command over the League fleet, so would Dorkis, the successor of
Pausanias, be Spartan nauarch.

His family was connected through proxenia with the family of the
Athenian Alcibiades. In 421 Endios went as an ambassador to Athens, to
complain about the alliance between Athens and Argos. In 413/2 he
belonged to the college of ephors and explained the Asia Minor politics
of his guest friend Alcibiades to it. After the battle of Cyzicus he
sought in vain for a peace in Athens.

Facts.Fact:
A Spartiate who especially distinguished himself in the naval
campaigns. In 412 he was detached by the Nauarch Astychos to Lesbos.
After that he was engaged as harmost of Thasos

from where he was driven
out by the party hostile to Sparta in 410. In 406 we find him by the
fleet of Kallikratidas. It fell to him after the catastrophe at
Arginusae with the remains of the ships and the army to hold out in
Chios until Lysander came with reinforcements in 405; and he probably
did this as nauarch of the year 406/5.
in which he played a famous part

he
was ordered to Thrace. In the year 400 we find him in Byzantium under
the command of Anaxibios. Around 389 he was stationed at Aegina for a
long time

from which he disturbed the Athenians. For his service he had
the honor of a statue in the monument of Lysander at Delphi. He also had
a statue at Ephesus.

Five times he won the boxing contest in Olympia. The first victory
was won as a boy. The other victories can best be placed in Ol. 45-48 =
600-588

since his father had won the men’s boxing in Ol. 39-42 =
624-608.

The circumstances of Eurydamidas are unclear

but he probably was
king during the latter part of the reign of Leonidas (1) II and the
early part of the reign of Kleomenes (1) III. Kleomenes III became his
stepfather.

Certainly he had died by the time Kleomenes tried to recall
Archidamos (3)

and it
may have been the death of Eurydamidas which raised the necessity of
placing a king on the Eurypontid throne. Kleomenes is said to have
poisoned Eurydamidas.

G. W. Bowersock, “Eurykles of Sparta,” JRS, LI (1961), 112-18o

Facts.Fact:
M. Antonius executed his father for piracy. Eurykles commanded a
ship

possibly a contingent of ships against Antonius at
Actium<sup>d</sup>.

and the island
of Cythera by Augustus<sup>fgn</sup>.
He visited the court of Herod

where he used the king's
family problems to enrich himself.<sup>ab</sup>

After his return to Greece he was exiled by Augustus for “having
filled Achaea with unrest

” probably by attempting to assert Sparta's
hegemony of the League of Free Laconia and the rest of the Peloponnesus.
His family remained in Sparta and his son

was eventually granted
the same status as his father<sup>aeho</sup>.

After his death Eurykles was honored with a festival instituted at
Gythium by AD 15l<sup>m</sup>.

From the noble family of the Cadmeian Argives he was supposed to have

A Spartiate who accompanied Dorieus on his expedition to Libya and
Sicily. He saved himself and the survivors of the battle at Egesta in
510 and forced his way into Selinuntum and ruled there. After a short
reign he was driven out and killed.

She won the four horse chariot race at Olympia and received a statue
for it in Sparta. Kyniska the sister of Agesilaos was the first Greek
woman (Pausanias III 8.1) allowed to compete with her horses, so the
victory of Euryleonis must come later &lt

A Spartiate who in winter 426/5 sought to take Delphi from Naupaktos.
After this miscarried he turned to Acarnania, were he fell in a battle
at Olpai against the Athenian Demosthenes.

Facts.Fact: The first Spartan king from the house of the Agids. He is

an invented person to explain the origin of the double
kingship. The ancient chronographers gave him a reign of 42 years

Sources.Resource:
Descendant, perhaps grandson, of king Damaratus and brother of
Prokles. In the year 399 we find both brothers as master over Pergamum,
Teuthrania, and Halisarna.

Was given the mission in 333 by Agis III to bring money and ships
from the Persians to Cape Taenarum. He is not categorically stated to be
Lacedaemonian but from the importance of the mission he certainly would
be.

A Spartan army leader, who was besieged by the Arcadians in 364 in
Kromnos. He appears around 352 in the struggle against Megalopolis and
died at an age of 80 years (thus born in 432). The time of his death is
established by Plutarch where king Archidamos and Agis were in the field
together against Megalopolis. That was possible only in 352. He must
have been a Spartiate since he fought in the immediate circle of the
king.

Facts.Fact:
A Spartiate who commanded in the Peloponnesian fleet after 412.
411/10 he held the position of epistoleus under the nauarch Mindaros.
After that he was harmost of Chalcedon and found his death in the
defense of this city in spring 409.

Facts.Fact:
He was an Olympic victor as the first in boxing of the boys (Ol 37 =
632) and five times in men's boxing (Ol. 39-43 = 624-608). According to
Pausanias he was accorded the same honors as were paid to Poseidon in
Sparta.

A Spartan youth who was supposed to have saved Gytheion in 370/69 from the Thebans. "Isidas" is certainly to be identified with "Isadas" above, the son of Phoebidas. The passage in Polyaenus is only a doublet of Plutarch Agesilaus 34 and confuses the two Theban invasions of 370/69 and 362.

In 421 as one of the empowered representatives of Sparta he signed
the peace of Nikias. Soon after that he travelled to Chalcidice. He must
have returned quickly since he was one of the signers of the
Spartan-Athenian alliance in 421.

Nauarch of the year 407/6. He took over the command in Spring 406
from Lysander. After a promising beginning

the invasion of Methymna and
the victory at Mytilene

he was defeated by the Athenians at Arginusae
and fell there. Aelian gives the information that K. was a μόθαξ.
(Poralla suspects the truth of that assertion

particularly as he is
linked with Lysander—“improbable”—and Gylippos—“false”—but

if a mothax
does not have to be a helot

but could be the son of a disenfranchised
citizen

then perhaps there is validity to these assertions.) Diodorus
describes him as a Spartiate.

A young man who in the first year of the reign of Agesilaos II was
condemned to death for a plot against the Spartiates. K. belonged to the
class of hypomeiones

as Xenophon excludes him from the class of
homoioi. This only makes sense if K. belonged in the widest sense to the
class of Spartiates.

Facts.Fact:
He may at some time (before 446) have conducted an operation against
Tegea.

In 446 as ephor he accompanied the young king Pleistoanax on his
operation against Athens. There

he accepted a bribe from
Pericles to retreat

and he fled from Sparta.
He travelled to Thurii (he may have been one of the oikists)

and fought as a general for his new fatherland
against the Tarentines and Lucanians.

Sources.Resource: Suidas s. v. ἔφοροι and εἰς τὸ δέον
Photius lexicon s. v. Θουριομάντεις (conjecture of Pappritz)

As adviser to Kallikratidas in the fleet in 406 he advised
Kallikratidas to accept 50 talents from the friends of Lysander to
murder one of their opponents. (“If I were Kallikratidas, I would accept
this offer.” “So would I, if I were Kleandros.”) In 400 he was harmost
in Byzantium.

King from the house of the Agids
Father of Agesipolis II and Kleomenes II
In 380 he followed his brother Agesipolis (I) to the throne.

In the beginning of 378 he led an expedition to Thebes to reinforce
the occupation of the Cadmeia. In Spring 376 he tried to force the pass
of Kithairon into Boeotia in vain.

In 374 for the first time he led an expedition into Phocis. In 371 he
marched from Phocis and died in the battle at Leuctra on the 5th of
August 371.

but Leonidas (1) in 254 BC "was

Eurysthenes<sup>c</sup>."
Agiad king of Sparta from the expulsion of Leonidas II to his return
at which time Kleombrotos was exiled<sup>ab</sup>.
Either he or Kleonymos (1) founded Heraea in Arcadia<sup>e</sup>.

Facts.Fact: Son of Leonidas (1) II and Kratesikleia

He carried through the reforms which Agis IV had conceived:
cancellation of debt

increasing thereby the strength of Sparta enough to regain the hegemony
of the Peloponnesus.

Unlike Agis he did not draw back from violence against his fellow
Spartiates. He had four ephors and a few of their adherents (whom he
thought would oppose reform) murdered and he exiled about eighty more
although he held an allotment of land for them.

to return from
Messene to Sparta to be king. Upon his return Archidamos was
murdered.

He waged war against the Achaean League and all but destroyed it; he
captured Argos.

Aratus induced the Macedonians to help the League and after two years
of indecisive engagements Kleomenes was defeated at Sellasia

He escaped to Egypt and committed suicide in 219 BC (According to
Polybius <XV 25.2> Sosibios

Sources.Resource: III 6.2-3h, 24.1i (—"Kleonymos son of Kleomenes son of Agesipolis," almost certainly an error for this Kleonymos, who was the son of Kleomenes and nephew of Agesipolis)

Facts.Fact: Father of Leonidas (1) II (born no later than ca. 300 BC)
Uncle and regent of Areus (1) I
When Kleomenes II died Kleonymos expected

that he would be chosen king. He was passed over in favor of his
brother's son Areus

but he was [made regent] and given command of the
armies<sup>h</sup>.

was a general of considerable ability. He
aided Tarentum against the Lucanians in 309/8 BC<sup>a</sup>. He annexed
Metapontum<sup>em</sup> and seized Corcyra

ca. 303 BC<sup>fg</sup>. He
aided Boeotia against Demetrius<sup>c</sup>

ca. 279 BC He was engaged in operations against
Messene<sup>j</sup> and Zarax<sup>i</sup>; he mediated a truce in Crete
between the Polyrhenians and Phalosarnians<sup>n</sup>.

The situation in Sparta became impossible for him after Areus I came
of age and began to assert his rights. Areus' son was supposed to have
committed adultery with Chilonis (but

the story may be considered
suspect). Kleonymos left

and accompanied him
in an invasion of Laconia<sup>d</sup>.

Facts.Fact: Father of Leonidas (1) II (born no later than ca. 300 BC)
Uncle and regent of Areus (1) I
When Kleomenes II died Kleonymos expected

that he would be chosen king. He was passed over in favor of his
brother's son Areus

but he was [made regent] and given command of the
armies<sup>h</sup>.

was a general of considerable ability. He
aided Tarentum against the Lucanians in 309/8 BC<sup>a</sup>. He annexed
Metapontum<sup>em</sup> and seized Corcyra

ca. 303 BC<sup>fg</sup>. He
aided Boeotia against Demetrius<sup>c</sup>

ca. 279 BC He was engaged in operations against
Messene<sup>j</sup> and Zarax<sup>i</sup>; he mediated a truce in Crete
between the Polyrhenians and Phalosarnians<sup>n</sup>.

The situation in Sparta became impossible for him after Areus I came
of age and began to assert his rights. Areus' son was supposed to have
committed adultery with Chilonis (but

the story may be considered
suspect). Kleonymos left

and accompanied him
in an invasion of Laconia<sup>d</sup>.

Facts.Fact:
A runner famous for his speed who won the Olympic games in the
diaulos. His grave was on the Eurotas (which is the reason for
identifying him as Spartan). The speed of L. was proverbial even in the
time of the empire. Ladas has the unusual distinction of being mentioned
more often by Latin authors than by Greek. Myron (mid-fifth century)
sculpted a statue of him. He had a statue in Argos. Ladas appears to be
a nickname based on the meaning “a dappled deer.” (Hsch. 48

Facts.Fact:
Under the name Leon we find a tradition of different deeds. A Leon
led out a colony in 426 as oikist to Herakleia in Tachinia<sup>c</sup>.
Another was ambassador to Athens in 420 and eponymous ephor in
419/8<sup>df</sup>. Also it was a Leon who in 411 took over the command
of the fallen Pedaritos in Chios<sup>e</sup>. Also the father of the
well-known Antalkidas and of Pedaritos was named Leon<sup>eg</sup>.

The question is whether we should attribute all these notices to one
Leon or whether we are dealing with different individuals of the same
name. If Preger (Theodor Christoph Preger
Inscriptiones Graecae metricae: ex scriptoribus praeter Anthologiam collectae

1977) n. 128 with his emendation is right
and Leon won in 440 with the horses of his father

the reason may have
been that he was too young to compete with his own horses; we could
think of Leon as 20-25 years old then
when he won the Olympic victory

so that it would be possible that Leon had a son Pedaritos who in 411
must have been already 30 years old and that his second son Antalkidas
in 393 already was in his maturity as he must have been to be an
ambassador. So must Leon in 411 have been about 50-55 years old

old
enough to have carried out an important diplomatic mission with Lichas
and yet not too old to have taken the command of his fallen son
Pedaritos. So Poralla proposes the following stemma

Sources.Resource: King from the house of the Agids

Facts.Fact: Son of the king Anaxandridas and his first wife

the daughter of his half brother Kleomenes I
and had with her a son Pleistarchos

After the death of Kleomenes I he accepted the rule about 487. In 480
he found a hero's death at the defense of Thermopylae. His bones were
brought back forty years later from Thermopylae to Sparta. In his honor
yearly games were held at his grave.

Facts.Fact: King from the house of the Eurypontids

but she taken away from him by
Damaratos

From his first marriage came a son Zeuxidamos. After this son’s early
death L. married Eurydame and had a single daughter Lampito.

In 491 he united with Kleomenes to drive out Damaratus and become
king in his place.

He helped Kleomenes in his scheme to take hostages among the
Aeginetans; later

he made a trip to
Athens and asked that the hostages be returned to Aegina.

In Spring 479 he sailed past Delos to Asia Minor and defeated the
Persian fleet at Mykale.

In 476 he led an army against the Aleuadae in Thessaly but took a
bribe to retreat. In the ensuing outcry he betook himself into exile in
Tegea
where he remained until his death in 469.

Facts.Fact: In 421 he was an ambassador in Argos.

he won a victory in the Olympic games
with the four-horse chariot and for that he had a portrait

As Argive proxenos he worked out the fifty years peace with Argos in
418.
He was known for dining the foreigners who visited Sparta during the gymnopaideia (Mem).

In winter 412/11 he was sent with Antisthenes to Asia Minor where he
met with Tissaphernes

repudiated the shameful agreement of Chalkideus
and Therimenes and concluded a new agreement. After that he died of
illness in Miletus. His death must have come in the summer of 411
shortly before the trip of Tissaphernes to Aspendos

since according to
Thucydides he was supposed to have accompanied Tissaphernes there. In
his place the Spartans sent Philippos.

Facts.Fact:
Since at the present state of research Lycurgus can no longer be
considered an historical personage

he is no longer a subject for a
prosopography

whether "Lycurgus" is a priestly title or whether we
should see in him a heroized god like Apollo Lykios or Zeus Lykaios is
immaterial. Nor should we concern ourselves with the different dates of
his supposed laws. In ancient times the date of Lycurgus was so much in
doubt that Timaeus believed there were two Lycurguses<sup>a</sup>.

The Lycurgus myth seems to have first been worked up in the fifth
century. At that time Hellanikos knew of no lawgiver Lycurgus and
attributed the organization of the state to Eurysthenes and
Prokles<sup>d</sup>. Herodotus I 65/66 already knew the lawgiving deeds
of Lykourgos and gave different accounts of the origins of the laws.
This contemporary uncertainty about the role of Lykurgos seems to have
affected the kinglists too. In Herodotus<sup>e</sup> he belongs to the
house of the Agids. He was here the brother of Labotas and regent of
Doryssos. This version seems to have disappeared and Lykurgos became a
collateral member of the less well known Eurypontid house. This is first
introduced to us under the name Simonides (who cannot be the
poet)<sup>a</sup>. But it must be older as the predecessors of Eunomos
in the Eurypontid list testify in Herodotus<sup>f</sup>. As Lykurgos
could not be placed in the already established list of the Eurypontid
kings
so someone invented a Eunomos and made him a brother sometimes

and sometimes the father of Lykurgos<sup>a</sup>. Then this Eunomos was
placed in the kings list. Genealogical speculation florished and
produced a rich number. Eunomos had two wives; from the first he had
Polydektes

he had Lykurgos.
This one in turn had two sons

Eukosmos and Antioros. In the royal house
itself Lykurgos found opposition
which is given substance by Leonidas
the brother of the wife of Polydektes<sup>abcg</sup>.

Was with Brasidas in 429, placed under the orders of the nauarch
Knemos, and in this duty took part in the battle at Naupactos and the
raid on Salamis
Athenaeus VI 233f, 234a, 271f (mothax), X 431d, XI 485c, XII 535d, 543b, 550de, XIII 555c, XV 696e (paeans sung to Lysander in Samos)
J-F. Bommelaer, Lysandre de Sparte, Histoire et Traditions, Bibliotheque des Écoles Françaises d’Athènes et de Rome, Fascicule 240, Paris, 1981

Facts.Fact:
He came from a branch of the royal Heraclid family not in the
succession to the throne (although Aelian<sup>a</sup> remarks that he
was a mothax). His family had a friendly relationship with the royal
family of Cyrene<sup>ke</sup>.
Lysandros had a brother Libys and a number of daughters. Descendants are still known in 225 bcfuB.

Lysandros took over the command as nauarch of the year 408/7 of the
waters near Asia Minor and in the spring of 407 defeated Antiochos at
Notion. At the end of the next winter he returned to
Sparta<sup>blxy</sup>.

As epistoleus of the nauarch Arakos Lysandros held the actual command
in the following years in Asia Minor and defeated the Athenians in
September 405 at Aigospotami. The base of the memorial Lysandros
dedicated at Delphi because of this victory is to be seen today at
Delphi<sup>iF</sup>.

After the victory Lysandros settled decarchies in Thrace and Asia
Minor and sailed to Athens to besiege it by sea<sup>cmnwz</sup>.
In this time the seizure of Samos must also fall

though a closer
dating is not possible<sup>doA</sup>.

In the year 403 Lysandros undertook a trip to Athens to support the
Thirty<sup>qB</sup>.

During a trip to the Hellespont Pharnabazos denounced him for his
harsh behavior and he was recalled to Sparta. He persuaded the ephors to
allow him to leave Sparta for a trip to Zeus Ammon<sup>ep</sup>.

During this time must fall his embassy to Dionysius of
Syracuse<sup>k</sup>.

After the death of Agis II Lysandros helped Agesilaos gain the throne
and accompanied him to Asia Minor in 396<sup>frvC</sup>.

After his return to Sparta he attempted to take away the two royal
families' exclusive right to the throne

but his plans were disrupted by
the outbreak of the war in Greece. He marched with an army to Phocis
where at the Haliartos in Autumn 395 he was defeated and killed. He was
buried at Panopeus in Phocis<sup>ehjstDE</sup>.

Sources.Resource: Athenaeus VI 233f, 234a, 271f (mothax), X 431d, XI 485c, XII 535d, 543b, 550de, XIII 555c, XV 696e (paeans sung to Lysander in Samos)
J-F. Bommelaer, Lysandre de Sparte, Histoire et Traditions, Bibliotheque des Écoles Françaises d’Athènes et de Rome, Fascicule 240, Paris, 1981

Facts.Fact:
He came from a branch of the royal Heraclid family not in the
succession to the throne (although Aelian<sup>a</sup> remarks that he
was a mothax). His family had a friendly relationship with the royal
family of Cyrene<sup>ke</sup>.
Lysandros had a brother Libys and a number of daughters. Descendants are still known in 225 bcfuB.

Lysandros took over the command as nauarch of the year 408/7 of the
waters near Asia Minor and in the spring of 407 defeated Antiochos at
Notion. At the end of the next winter he returned to
Sparta<sup>blxy</sup>.

As epistoleus of the nauarch Arakos Lysandros held the actual command
in the following years in Asia Minor and defeated the Athenians in
September 405 at Aigospotami. The base of the memorial Lysandros
dedicated at Delphi because of this victory is to be seen today at
Delphi<sup>iF</sup>.

After the victory Lysandros settled decarchies in Thrace and Asia
Minor and sailed to Athens to besiege it by sea<sup>cmnwz</sup>.
In this time the seizure of Samos must also fall

though a closer
dating is not possible<sup>doA</sup>.

In the year 403 Lysandros undertook a trip to Athens to support the
Thirty<sup>qB</sup>.

During a trip to the Hellespont Pharnabazos denounced him for his
harsh behavior and he was recalled to Sparta. He persuaded the ephors to
allow him to leave Sparta for a trip to Zeus Ammon<sup>ep</sup>.

During this time must fall his embassy to Dionysius of
Syracuse<sup>k</sup>.

After the death of Agis II Lysandros helped Agesilaos gain the throne
and accompanied him to Asia Minor in 396<sup>frvC</sup>.

After his return to Sparta he attempted to take away the two royal
families' exclusive right to the throne

but his plans were disrupted by
the outbreak of the war in Greece. He marched with an army to Phocis
where at the Haliartos in Autumn 395 he was defeated and killed. He was
buried at Panopeus in Phocis<sup>ehjstDE</sup>.

He brought help in 457 to the Dorians against the Phocaeans as regent
for his nephew Pleistoanax and on his return march defeated the
Athenians at Tanagra. Probably Nikomedes had been regent since the death
of Pausanias.

Facts.Fact:
Sent by the Spartan government at the request of the
Carthaginians(?)<sup>c</sup>

he commanded a Carthaginian army in the
First Punic War. He defeated a Roman consular army and captured its
commander

255 BC. Shortly after his victory he sailed for
home<sup>a</sup>.

Tradition had it that he was murdered by the
Carthaginians<sup>de</sup>.
Xanthippos is a unique name Spartan name. Is it found in the family of Leotychidas II because of his friendship with Xanthippos the father of Pericles?

Carthaginians(?)<sup>c</sup>

he commanded a Carthaginian army in the
First Punic War. He defeated a Roman consular army and captured its
commander

255 BC. Shortly after his victory he sailed for
home<sup>a</sup>.

Tradition had it that he was murdered by the
Carthaginians<sup>de</sup>.
Xanthippos is a unique name Spartan name. Is it found in the family of Leotychidas II because of his friendship with Xanthippos the father of Pericles?

Sources.Resource: L. Ampelius Liber Memorialis (Terzaghi, 1943) 14. Duces et reges Lacedaemoniorum 9. Xanthippus

Silius Italicus II [305], 434, IV 357, 361, VI [327-8],
681-3<sup>e</sup>, IX 67
Bevan, House of Ptolemy 194-196 (St. Jerome on Daniel xi 7-9): is the "Xanthippus" in Ptolemy III's army the Spartan Xanthippus?

Facts.Fact:
One of the thirty Spartiates who accompanied Agesilaos II on the
campaign in Asia Minor. On the retreat from Asia Minor he was taken
prisoner in Larissa in 394 but was soon freed through the efforts of
Agesilaos.

He was sent by the Spartan regime to help Cyrus. In the Anabasis I 2.21 Xenophon names in place of Samios a "Pythagoras" as nauarch. One may guess, that Xenophon, whose Anabasis was published under a pseudonym, also used a pseudonym here, and a "Samios" lies very near to a "Pythagoras." This Samios appears to be the grandson of the foregoing Samios and the son of Archias, cf. Ἀρχιάς (Poralla 151)

A Eurypontid king inserted into the list between Prokles and Eurypon.

formation of helotry and a war against Arcadia.

Facts.Fact:
“In a little room in the schoolhouse [in Kardamyli] was a rose
antique funerary slab with a beautifully incised epitaph in Hellenistic
character commemorating the great love and respect that all his
contemporaries felt for the deceased

‘the Ephebe Sosicles the
Lacedaemonian.’ The inscription ended with a delicate curved loop of
knotted and fluttering ribbon.”

Sources.Resource: IG V 1. 65a, 111b (Σωσικράτης Σώτου, [gerousias] in the year of Sejanus— Σώτου is an inscriber’s error—Bradford Chiron 10, 1980, 423), 182 (cf. SEG XI 596)c

Facts.Fact: Stepbrother of King Agesilaos II and Kyniska
after the death of Archidamos II

between Eupolia and
Theodoros<sup>bd</sup>. Around 392 Teleutias together with Agesilaos
destroyed the wall of Lechaion<sup>d</sup>. Afterwards he was occupied
in the sea war. Did he hold three nauarchies? According to
Xenophon<sup>e</sup> Teleutias came to the fleet

which Herippidas
(after the nauarch Podanemos was killed) took over and most likely T.
was appointed then as nauarch. Then sometime in 390 Teleutias took over
the fleet of the nauarch Ekdikos

was then for a long time busy in
Rhodes and turned past Aigina back home<sup>f</sup>. In both cases we
see that Teleutias entered into the position of nauarch and occupied it
for a long time. Since there was no other sea campaign we must either
conclude that Teleutias was nauarch or that the nauarch did not command
the fleet in the area of operations (which by Lacedaemonian custom is
certainly possible<sup>c</sup>). During his third nauarchy Teleutias was
harassed at Aigina from Athens<sup>g</sup>. In summer 382 he marched to
Chalkidike

where in spring 381 he was defeated and killed by the
Olynthians<sup>ah</sup>.

Facts.Fact:
A Spartiate who took part in the battle of Mantinea in 418 as an
adviser of king Agis II<sup>a</sup>. He also participated in the battle
at Aegospotami<sup>d</sup>. As nauarch of the year 398/7 he was occupied
in the theater of war in Asia Minor<sup>ceg</sup>. In 396/5 he was with
Dionysius of Syracuse and supported him in his war against
Carthage<sup>b</sup>. In summer 390 he found himself at the Isthmus with
Agesilaos<sup>f</sup>.

A Laconian from Pellana on the Eurotas, who won the boxing for boys
at Olympia. His time is established by the fact that he had a statue
done by Myron (fl. ca. 480-440). Pausanias calls Philip Azanian since
Pellana was given to the Arcadians by Philip.

Aspendos in the place of the dead Lichas in summer 411. His diplomatic
mission proves that he was a Spartiate.

Was occupied in negotiating the armistice between Athens and Sparta
in 422 and signed the peace of Nicias in the following year. After that
he travelled with Klearidas to Thrace and swore to the alliance with
Athens after his return in the summer 421. In the next year he went
again on a diplomatic mission to Athens.

Facts.Fact: He was the father of a daughter

whose name is not given but deduced. Chilon was considered in
antiquity as one of the seven wise men and many sayings are attributed
to him. He lived in the time of the Pisistratids and was eponymous ephor
of the year 556/5. Chilon was supposed to have been the first ephor. In
any case he was the author of a reform of the ephoria in some major
aspect. He died shortly after his ephoria. His daughter (cf. Δαμάρμενος)
had probably a second son Damarmenos

whose grandchildren intermarried
with the collateral members of the royal houses. Chilon later received
divine honors in Sparta.

Facts.Fact: A Lacedaemonian who won seven victories at the Olympic games

four
times in the stadion and three times in the distance run and so had
statues in his honor at Sparta and Olympia. Africanus gives only three
stadion victories to Chionis (Ol 29

31) and names Charmis as victor
of the stadion in Ol 28. That must be an error since Pausanias mentions
the victories of Chionis several times and consistently lists Ol 28 as
his first victory. He was supposed to have accompanied Battos as founder
to Cyrene.

The chronology of his office is loaded with difficulties since Pollis
was nauarch in 396/95 and Peisandros for 395/4 and so there is no room
for Cheirikrates (but the Oxyrhynchus historian writes that he arrived
as nauarch and the successor of Pollis). A couple of solutions have been
proposed: that Ch. filled out an abbreviated term of Pollis or that
Peisandros was appointed to a command by Agesilaus but was not actually
nauarch.

The chronology of his office is loaded with difficulties since Pollis
was nauarch in 396/95 and Peisandros for 395/4 and so there is no room
for Cheirikrates (but the Oxyrhynchus historian writes that he arrived
as nauarch and the successor of Pollis). A couple of solutions have been
proposed: that Ch. filled out an abbreviated term of Pollis or that
Peisandros was appointed to a command by Agesilaus but was not actually
nauarch.

Facts.Fact:
A Spartiate from the number of the homoioi. In 401 he commanded the
forward elements of the detachment of Cyrus' army in agreement with
Sparta. After Clearchus was taken prisoner by Tissaphernes Ch. became
the commander in chief of the Greek mercenaries. (Xenophon implies that
Ch. took part in the expedition of Cyrus at the behest of Sparta.
Moreover he allows that Ch took over the high command first in Sinope.
Xenophon would not otherwise have related the choice of Cheirisophos to
the supreme command

if he had not been forced through the account of the part of the army in Herakleia. Also in various parts of the Anabasis Ch has already exercized the supreme command.) He led the army to Trapezus and betook himself to Byzantium to fetch over ships. His request was rejected by the Spartan nauarch Anaxibios and he returned to the army and died in Kalpe.
